ingest_project: P0380-Slavery, Enslaved Persons, and Free Blacks in the Americas Collection / Frederick Douglas Collection / Wakefield Vellum Documents
library_unit: Charles Deering McCormick Library of Special Collections
project: {'cycle': '2022', 'desc': 'From a decentering whiteness standpoint, this project would add value to the body of available materials available online documenting Frederick Douglass. It would also contribute to available documentation such as manumission papers and bills of sale, which are being used in projects like enslaved.org to facilitate genealogical and historical research on individual enslaved people around the globe.', 'manager': 'Jen Young', 'name': 'Slavery, Enslaved Persons, and Free Blacks in the Americas Collection / Frederick Douglas Collection / Wakefield Vellum Documents', 'proposer': 'Benn Joseph', 'task_number': 'P0380'}
provenance: J.C. Shaffer, a Northwestern University patron, donated these materials to the university library. J.C. Shaffer's brother, W.H. Shaffer, purchased “certain papers” of Douglass from Benjamin Auld, son of Douglass’ enslaver, for $125 in 1896 (see Folder 2, Item 5). The bill of sale (Folder 1) and two letters from Frederick Douglass to the Aulds (Folder 2, Items 3-4) are referenced in an 1895 Indianapolis Journal article as being owned by Benjamin Auld and are also referenced in the letter from Auld to J.C. Shaffer (Folder 2, Item 6), along with the letters from Anna Richardson and Walter Lowrie (Folder 2, Items 1-2). It is unclear which items W.H. or J.C. Shaffer purchased directly from the Aulds.
series: Frederick Douglass Collection -- Frederick Douglass Correspondence, 1846-97
subject: African American abolitionists|African Americans|Douglass, Frederick, 1818-1895|Freed persons|Social reformers|Statesmen|Enslaved persons
title: Helen Douglass to J.C. Shaffer. Cedar Hill, Anacostia, D.C. 2pp. Re: Frederick Douglass
